qas.question: Before the Enlightenment, most intellectual debates revoled around what subject?
Catholic, Lutheran, Reformed (Calvinist), or Anglican issues were called what?
During what time period did a "general process of rationalization and secularization set in"?

answers.text: second half of the 17th century and during the 18th century

qas.question: The aim of confessional debates was to establish which bloc of faith should have what?

answers.text: the "monopoly of truth and a God-given title to authority"

context: The debating societies discussed an extremely wide range of topics. Before the Enlightenment, most intellectual debates revolved around <a0_0><a1_0>"confessional"<a1_0/><a0_0/> – that is, Catholic, Lutheran, Reformed (Calvinist), or Anglican issues, and the main aim of these debates was to establish which bloc of faith ought to have <a3_0>the "monopoly of truth and a God-given title to authority"<a3_0/>. After this date everything thus previously rooted in tradition was questioned and often replaced by new concepts in the light of philosophical reason. After the <a2_0>second half of the 17th century and during the 18th century<a2_0/>, a "general process of rationalization and secularization set in," and confessional disputes were reduced to a secondary status in favor of the "escalating contest between faith and incredulity".
